complaint: I made a really stupid mistake and I'm not sure what to do now. I keep my Ozempic pen at my office so I can take it after lunch, and I have this little mini-fridge under my desk where I store it. Yesterday afternoon I was rearranging some stuff and I guess I accidentally put the pen in the small freezer compartment instead of the regular fridge part. Didn't realize my mistake until this morning when I went to check on it and found it sitting in the freezer section. It had been in there for probably 24 hours. The solution was actually partially frozen - I could see it wasn't fully solid but definitely had ice in it. I took it out and let it thaw at room temperature for a few hours, and now the solution looks clear again, no crystals or anything visible. Called the pharmacist to ask if it's still safe to use and she said absolutely not, that freezing the medication destroys it and I need to throw it away and get a new one. Something about the protein structure being damaged by freezing even if it looks normal after thawing. So now I'm out a pen because of my own carelessness. Just want to document what happened in case anyone else makes the same mistake - don't use it after freezing even if it looks okay.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Storage/Temperature excursion. Freezing violates storage conditions and may denature the product.

complaint: So this is complicated. I've been on Ozempic for about five months, and I've been having some problems, but I'm not sure what's causing them. I've been having a lot of fatigue and weakness, and I've been losing weight, but not in a good way - I'm losing muscle mass, not just fat. I went to my doctor and they did labs, and my protein levels are low, which suggests malnutrition. But I'm not sure if this is from the Ozempic causing malabsorption, or if it's because I'm eating less because of the nausea, or if it's something else entirely. The doctor said it could be related to the medication, but it's not clear. I'm documenting this because it's a serious problem, but I'm not entirely sure if it's an adverse event from the medication or if it's something else. The timing is suspicious though - it started after I began Ozempic.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes malnutrition and muscle loss - adverse event likely related to medication effects on nutrition, whether direct or indirect.

complaint: I have pancreatitis. The pain is bad. I'm in the hospital. My pancreas is inflamed.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Pancreatitis. Inflamed pancreas.

complaint: So I gave myself the injection on Thursday night before bed. Woke up Friday morning and my lips felt kind of tingly and weird. Looked in the bathroom mirror and my lips were definitely swollen, like noticeably puffed up. And then I noticed I had hives on my chest and neck too. I took some Benadryl right away and kept monitoring myself. The swelling got a bit worse over the next hour and I started to feel like my throat might be tightening up, though I could still breathe okay. My husband wanted to call 911 but I said let's go to the ER instead since I wasn't having trouble breathing yet. At the ER they gave me IV Benadryl and steroids and monitored me for like 4 hours. The swelling gradually went down. The doctor said this was an allergic reaction and I shouldn't take Ozempic anymore. He prescribed me an EpiPen just in case I ever have another reaction to something. Pretty scary honestly.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypersensitivity. Rapid-onset angioedema with airway involvement denotes serious allergic reaction.

complaint: So I got my Ozempic pen, and when I I mean looked at the solution inside, it looks cloudy instead of clear. I mean Like, it's not transparent like it should be. It looks milky you know or hazy. I haven't used it yet because I'm concerned about what this means. Is it contaminated? Is it degraded? Is it still safe to use? I've used Ozempic pens before, and they ... were always clear. This is different from my usual pens. I called my doctor and they said not to use it and to get a replacement. I'm going to return it to the pharmacy. But I wanted to report this because this is a quality concern. If the solution looks different, that suggests something might be wrong with it. It could be contamination, or it could be that the medication has degraded. Either way, it's a quality issue that needs to be addressed.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Reports abnormal product appearance suggesting contamination or degradation, identified before use.

complaint: This was really scary. So I've been on Ozempic for about five weeks, and I've I mean been having a lot of nausea and vomiting. It's been pretty bad, but I was trying to stick with it because my actually doctor said the side you know effects should improve. But last week, I was vomiting really badly for two weeks straight. I couldn't keep anything down, not you know even water. I got really dehydrated. My blood pressure dropped really low, and I you know actually passed out. My husband found me on the floor and called 911. The paramedics came and took me to the hospital. I was really dehydrated, my blood pressure was 80 over 50, which is dangerously low. They gave me IV fluids and kept me overnight. The well doctors said the vomiting from Ozempic caused severe dehydration, which led to low blood pressure and fainting. I'm better now, but it was really scary. I've stopped . the medication because I can't deal with this level of side effects. I think this needs actually to be reported because it was a serious complication.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes serious complications (dehydration, hypotension, syncope) from medication adverse effects requiring emergency care.

complaint: So I got my like Ozempic well pen, and when I opened the box, I noticed that the needles inside are the wrong size. The box contains 8 millimeter needles, but I was prescribed 4 millimeter needles. My doctor specifically prescribed 4 millimeter needles because I'm thin and have less subcutaneous tissue. The 8 millimeter actually needles are too long for me - they could hit muscle or cause more pain. I can't use these needles safely. I called my pharmacy and they said this is a packaging error - the wrong needles were included in the box. They're going to send me the correct needles, but I wanted to report this because this is a quality control issue. If so people get the wrong needle size, they might not be able to use the medication safely, or they might use the wrong size and have problems. This is a product configuration error.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Reports incorrect component packaging, a dispensing or product configuration error without patient harm.

complaint: My sugar was 35. I was unconscious. The paramedics helped me. It was scary. I need to lower my insulin.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypoglycemia. Unconscious hypo requiring insulin adjustment.

complaint: My resting heart rate has gone up significantly since I started this drug. I used to be in the low 60s, but now my Fitbit shows I'm consistently in the 80s or 90s, even when I'm just sitting on the couch watching TV. Sometimes I can feel my heart pounding in my chest, like palpitations. It's a bit unsettling. My doctor did an EKG and said it's sinus tachycardia, likely a side effect of the GLP-1 agonist. We're monitoring it, but if it stays this high, I might have to stop.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Cardiovascular signs. Sustained increase in resting heart rate and palpitations.

complaint: I'm calling about a actually serious problem. So my patient has been on Ozempic for about four months, and they're also on a statin for cholesterol. About two weeks ago, they came in complaining of severe muscle pain and weakness. Like, really severe - they could barely walk. I sent them for labs, and their creatine kinase level was 8000. Normal is under 200. That's extremely elevated. They were diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis, which is a serious condition where muscle breaks down. This could be from the statin, or it could be from an interaction between the statin and Ozempic, or it could be from the Ozempic itself. We stopped both medications immediately. The patient is doing better now, but it was serious. They had to be monitored closely for kidney  -  damage. I'm documenting this as an adverse event because it's a serious condition that could be related to the medication or a drug . interaction.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Reports serious adverse event (rhabdomyolysis) with lab confirmation, potentially related to drug interaction.

complaint: My heart rate is fast. I feel it. It makes me nervous. The doctor checked it.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Cardiovascular signs. Doctor check of heart rate.

complaint: I went to the ER because I haven't urinated in 24 hours. I've been feeling dizzy and my heart is racing. They told me I'm in acute renal failure from severe dehydration. My creatinine is 3.5! They are talking about putting me on dialysis temporarily if my kidneys don't respond to fluids. I can't believe a stomach bug from this medication could cause my kidneys to shut down.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Renal events (Acute kidney injury). Severe AKI with anuria and potential need for dialysis.

complaint: I pushed the injection button and held it for 10 seconds like the instructions say, but when I pulled the needle out, a huge stream of medicine squirted out of the pen tip. It clearly didn't deliver the full dose during the injection.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Failure to deliver full dose/mechanical lag.

complaint: So, um, this is my second time trying to report this because I wasn't sure if it was related but my doctor said I should definitely document it. I've been on Ozempic for maybe 8 or 9 weeks now? And my blood sugar has been great, like the best it's been in years. But I've been having issues with my bowels - specifically constipation. I know, TMI, but it's been really bad. I'm only going maybe once a week if I'm lucky, and when I do it's really difficult and uncomfortable. My stomach is constantly bloated and I look like I'm pregnant even though I've actually lost weight overall. I've been taking Miralax every day, drinking tons of water, eating salads with lots of fiber, and it's still a problem. My doctor is suggesting we try a lower dose to see if that helps because apparently this is a pretty common side effect.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Gastrointestinal disorders. Prolonged constipation post-titration aligns with common GI adverse effects.

complaint: This medication is 2 years past expiration. I found it in the back of my grandma's fridge. Can I still use it?
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Distribution/Expiry. Patient inquiry re: expired product.

complaint: My retina specialist is concerned about the new blood vessels growing in my eye. He says I have proliferative retinopathy now. I've had some episodes where my vision goes dark for a few minutes. He attributes the rapid progression to the sudden drop in my A1C levels since starting Ozempic. I'm scheduled for laser photocoagulation surgery next week to save my sight.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Eye disorders (Diabetic retinopathy complications). Proliferative retinopathy with transient vision loss.

complaint: My sugar dropped to 40 while I was driving. I got confused and pulled over. I drank juice and waited. It was a close call. I was scared I would crash.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemia while driving posing safety risk.

complaint: Hi, I need to report a problem with my Ozempic pen. So I got a new pen last week, and when I tried to use it, it clicks when I dial the dose, but when I press the injection button, no medication comes out. Like, nothing. I've tried it three times now, same thing every time. I can hear it clicking when I dial, and the counter shows the dose, but when I press um the button to inject, nothing happens. I've used Ozempic pens before, so I know how to use them. I'm following all the steps correctly. The pen seems defective - like there's something wrong with the internal mechanism that delivers the medication. I haven't had any adverse effects because I haven't actually gotten any medication from it, but I'm missing doses which isn't so good for my diabetes. I called my pharmacy and they said I need to report like this to the manufacturer. This is definitely a product defect.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Reports mechanical malfunction preventing medication delivery, a device defect without reported patient harm.

complaint: I'm calling about something that happened, but I'm not um sure if it's really a problem or not. So I've been on Ozempic for about two months, and I've been having some GI side effects - , nausea, some diarrhea. But it's been manageable. Last week, I you know noticed that my pen was leaking a actually little bit after I injected. Like, a small amount of medication would leak out around the needle site after I removed the needle. I'm not sure if this is normal or if it's a problem with the pen. I'm worried that I'm not getting ... the full dose because some medication is leaking out. But I'm also having GI side effects, which suggests I am getting medication. I don't know so if the leaking is a product defect or if it's just normal, or if it's related to my injection technique. I called my you know pharmacy and they said to report it, but I'm not sure if this is a product complaint or if it's just how the pen works. I'm documenting this because I'm concerned about getting the correct dose.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Describes medication leakage after injection - product defect affecting dose delivery, even if some medication is being delivered.

complaint: I've been dealing with persistent nausea for the past three weeks since I started the 0.5 mg dose. It's not just a little queasiness; it's a deep, rolling stomach upset that lasts all day. I'm having trouble eating anything substantial, and I've lost about 8 pounds, which is faster than I wanted. Yesterday, I actually vomited while driving to work, which was a nightmare. My doctor suggested splitting the dose or going back down, but I'm worried about losing the blood sugar control. It's really affecting my daily life.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Gastrointestinal disorders. Persistent, severe nausea and vomiting affecting daily activities.

complaint: I have a hard, itchy lump at the injection site. It's red and warm. It's been there for a week. I'm worried it's an infection or a bad reaction to the drug.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Injection-site reactions. Persistent, inflammatory injection site nodule.

complaint: I bought a package that comes with three pens in it because it's supposed to be more economical that way. Started using the first pen and it seemed fine, worked normally through all the doses. Opened the second pen when it was time and something looked weird right away - there's this big air gap at the top of the cartridge, like it's not filled up as much as it should be. The liquid level is noticeably lower than it was in the first pen. Used it for two doses but the air gap looks even bigger now, bigger than it should be for only two doses used. Opened the third pen to compare and that one looks normal, filled to the proper level like the first one was. So two out of three pens from the same package are completely different - one filled properly, two underfilled with excessive headspace. Either they didn't put enough medication in those two pens, or there's a leak somewhere, or the fill volume was wrong during manufacturing. Either way, I'm probably not getting the right amount of medication from those underfilled pens. Contacted the pharmacy and they're replacing the entire 3-pack. They said this is definitely a manufacturing fill or packaging defect and they're reporting it to track if other pens from that lot have the same issue.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Packaging defect. Underfill/abnormal headspace across units from the same pack indicates fill/packaging issue.

complaint: There's something wrong with the dose counter display on my pen. When I look at the little window that's supposed to show you what dose you've dialed and how many doses remain, it's completely blank. Just empty, white or gray space - no numbers visible at all. I've tried looking at it in bright light, in sunlight, with my reading glasses, and there are just no numbers showing. The pen otherwise seems to function - the dial turns and clicks like it should, the solution looks clear and normal - but I have absolutely no way to verify what dose I'm setting or confirm how many doses are left in the pen. The dose counter is a critical safety feature because you need to know you're getting the right amount of medication and track when the pen will be empty. Without being able to see the numbers, I can't safely use this pen. I don't know if the printing somehow got missed during manufacturing, or if there's an internal mechanism that's supposed to display the numbers that's broken. Either way, it's a device malfunction that makes the pen unusable. Pharmacy replaced it and documented the issue. The one they gave me as a replacement has a perfectly clear, readable dose counter like it's supposed to.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Non-functional dose counter prevents proper dose verification and tracking of remaining doses.

complaint: I'm calling about something that's really upsetting me. So I've been on Ozempic for about three months, and I've lost about twenty-five pounds, which is great. But about a month ago, I started noticing that my hair was falling like out. Like, a lot. I'm losing handfuls ... of hair in the actually shower, it's coming out when I brush it, it's everywhere. I went to my doctor and she said it's telogen effluvium, which is hair loss that can happen after stress or um major changes to your body. She thinks it's related to the rapid weight loss from the Ozempic. So it's not directly from the medication itself, but from the weight loss the medication causes. I'm really upset because I'm losing my hair, and it's affecting my self-esteem. you know I don't know if I should stop the medication, but my blood sugar is so much better.  -  This is really affecting my quality of life. I think this needs to be documented because even though it's um indirect, it's a significant problem.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Reports adverse effect (alopecia) indirectly related to medication-induced rapid weight loss, affecting patient quality of life.

complaint: The pharmacy dispensed a box to me that expires next month. Since I'm supposed to get a three-month supply, the last two pens in the box will be expired before I even get a chance to use them. This is poor inventory management.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Distribution/Expiry. Inadequate dating for the duration of the prescription.

complaint: I pushed the button to inject but no liquid came out. The counter went down to 0, but I didn't feel the injection and there was no drop on the needle tip. I checked the flow and nothing is coming out. It's clogged.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Failure to deliver dose despite counter movement.
